---
title: Anthropometric characteristics, physical fitness, and throwing velocity in
  elite women's handball teams
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-PQ8XGFSZ" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Saavedra, J. M., Kristjánsdóttir, H., Einarsson, I. Þ., Guðmundsdóttir, M. L., Þorgeirsson, S., &#38; Stefánsson, A. (2018). Anthropometric characteristics, physical fitness, and throwing velocity in elite women’s handball teams. <i>Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research</i>, <i>32</i>(8), 2294. <a href="https://doi.org/10.1519/JSC.0000000000002412">https://doi.org/10.1519/JSC.0000000000002412</a></div> </div>

<div id="csl-bib-meta-PQ8XGFSZ" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-PQ8XGFSZ" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Saavedra et al. conducted a study on elite women's handball teams to understand how physical characteristics and fitness impact performance. They examined 80 players from different age groups, including the national A Team and under-19, under-17, and under-15 teams. The study found that weight, jumping ability, medicine ball throw, and endurance differed between the A Team and the under-19 team. They developed models predicting performance based on these factors, correctly classifying 76% of A Team players and 90% of under-19 players. Throwing speed was linked to height, weight, jumping ability, and medicine ball throw. These insights can help coaches tailor training to improve performance in elite female handball players.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-PQ8XGFSZ" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Anthropometric Characteristics, Physical Fitness, Throwing Velocity, Elite Women's Handball, Performance Prediction
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-PQ8XGFSZ" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    The aims of this study were: (i) to analyse anthropometric, physical fitness, and throwing speed in women elite handball players of different ages, and (ii) to develop a multivariate model explaining handball performance from a multidimensional perspective. Eighty women handball players (18.2±4.0 years in age) from National Team selections participated in the study. The players belonged to A Team, under-19, under-17, and under-15 national teams. All were evaluated by basic anthropometry, physical fitness tests, and handball throwing speed. A one-way ANOVA was used to establish the differences between teams with a Bonferroni post-hoc test. For each team, a discriminant analysis was performed to determine the predictor variables of performance. Pearson's simple correlation coefficients were calculated between each of the variables. The results of this particular study showed that (i) between the A Team and the U19 team, there were only differences in weight, CMJ, medicine ball throw, and yo-yo test, (ii) the A Team and U19 predictive models correctly classified 76% and 90% of the samples, respectively, with the variables involved being weight and BMI (A Team) and 30 m sprint and 7 m throwing speed (U19 team), and (iii) the 7 m and 9 m throwing speeds were correlated with each other and with stature, weight, CMJ, and medicine ball throw (0.367≤r≤0.533; 0.001≤p≤0.05). These results could help improve coaches' knowledge of elite female teams in the particular in the country where the study was conducted and in others of similar characteristics
  </article>
